issues.title: Make keyboard shortcuts work (better)
issues.body:
This one has really bugged me since [2015](https://github.com/ceylon/ceylon-ide-eclipse/issues/1513): the shortcut `⌘⇧T` disappears, and there is no easy way to access "Open Declaration". I'm guessing other shortcuts are affected as well.

I now know a workaround, but I'm guessing most users would just go on missing this feature.

The problem is that when re-installing the plugin (e.g., instal a new version of Eclipse & the Ceylon plugin but keep the same workspace), the "old" perspective is renamed to "<Ceylon>", but the keyboard bindings rely on it being named "Ceylon" (without the weird angle brackets). By default, the workspace will continue to display the "old" perspective that has been renamed.

The workaround is to "Save perspective as" "Ceylon" (overwriting the newly installed duplicate perspective). The perspective and all files must then be re-opened.

Note that the dependence on the perspective name also prevents users from being able to have multiple custom Ceylon perspectives (I guess some users find that useful?)

I don't know what the right fix is, but there *must* be some solution, like not re-creating and re-naming perspectives if they already exist or not depending on the workspace name for key bindings.

I couldn't reproduce the problem, but at least I catch the exception
(that comes from JDT) correctly in the `JDTModelLoader`, and log a
precise message with the type name. That will allow reproducing and
debugging the problem more easily if it reappears.

issues.title: Completion popup not showing automatically when I type letters
issues.body:
On a simple hello world module, I enabled "Auto-activate completion proposal list", set it to "both" with a delay of "1ms". When I type a period, the popup is shown, but it doesn't work when I type letters.

When typing the following code:

```ceylon
shared void coin() {
	1.a
}
```

`and` and `absolute` should be shown automatically, but I have to explicitly call ctrl-space to show the popup.

issues.title: Annotation processors don't work inside the Eclipse plugin

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
for #1854 (annotation processors don't work):

also register the overriden Javac components (task listener, model
loader, compiler delegate) into the Javac context during each annotation
processor round (which create a new Language compiler each time)

issues.body:
The Eclipse plugin uses an overridden Java backend compiler (in order to reuse the already typechecked model), and the changes made in the Java backend to support annotation processing rounds also required some changes in the eclipse Plugin / Java backend integration.
So currently annotation processors don't work correctly in the Eclipse plugin on Ceylon projects.

issues.body:
In **Ceylon IDE 1.3.0.v20160916** and **Eclipse Neon**, in the _Problems_ view, with the down arrow select _Configure Contents..._ then uncheck _All Errors_ and check _Errors/Warnings on Project_. After clicking _OK_, no Ceylon errors or warnings are displayed anymore.

Even after restarting Eclipse, completion attempts fail immediately with "no proposals".

This also happened shortly before release. I then installed a release candidate build of the plugin from a url provided by @davidfestal, and this fixed the issue. But, yesterday, it happened again, without any changes to my installation that I am aware of.

issues.title: Double dots

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Globally make completion non-blocking.

For #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a background thread)

Fixes also:
- #1814 : Very slow auto-completion work
- #1815 : Double dots

There were 2 main problems:

- the UI was frozen because we had to construct completions in another
thread, and run the `Display` event loop manually while waiting for the
result.
Doing this now allows registering a document-change listener that
cancels the completion search as soon as some new text is typed in the
editor.

- the images should not be retrieved during the completion construction
(this can causes a dead-lock), but lazily when
`CompletionProposal.getImage()` is called.

Additionally, this commit also enables retrieving partial fast
completion results when in auto-activation mode, or when a build is
running. Each time a partial completion result is returned, a warning is
shown in the status bar.

issues.title: Ceylon classpath containers should be exported by default
issues.body: If a Java project depends on a Ceylon project, it needs the classpath containers to be exported. There's _no way_ that any user is ever going to realize that, so they should be exported by default.

issues.title: Eclipse performance (with better info)
issues.body:
With the eclipse UI responsivity diagnosis and some luck, I was able to pinpoint two things.

First, I am reliably unable to switch panels in the eclipse preferences while a ceylon program is running from the IDE. As soon as the program stops, I see the new preferences page. Not even minimizing the main UI solves the block, which helped in many other occassions.

While the use case is admittedly weak, the contention that causes the delay it is likely to be a major driver for #1706. I hope this is reproducible somewhere.

Then, I got served an interesting stack trace / frame:

```
at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.code.navigator.CeylonNavigatorLabelProvider.getImage(CeylonNavigatorLabelProvider.java:257)
```

This seems to be a very expensive fall-back path; I actually got three of these during a 7 second outage (according to the UI responsiveness tooling; I could swear they miss half the fun).

The net effect seems to be a trawl through all .cars and probably more during the LinkEditorAction - i.e. on the UI thread. I'm not an expert on this topic but I'm certain there is room for improvement.

issues.title: Rename refactoring places ill-fomed imports with keyword package names

commitsDetails.commitMessage: fix #1765 handle escaped package names in rename package

issues.body:
If I rename packages (with subpackages) that have keyword sub-packages, the new imports are illegal.

E.g. a.x -> a.y leads a.x.out to become a.y.out, but imports and package declarations of that identifier are not protected (a.y.\iout). In fact they become a.y.outut in some places, probably because the protection which was there before is not being accounted for.

issues.title: mangled identifier with rename refactoring
issues.body:
If you have an unsaved file, rename refactoring may not work correctly.

Start with the files below, saved:

`fileA.ceylon`:

``` ceylon
void foo() {}
```

`fileB.ceylon`:

``` ceylon
void bar() => foo();
```

Then:
1. Add a space character before `void bar` in `fileB.ceylon`, so that there will be unsaved changes
2. CMD-Option-R on `fileA.ceylon`'s `foo`. Rename to `fooBar`
3. Click "OK" in the "Save Modified Resources" dialog that will appear

The result in `fileB.ceylon` will be `void bar() =>fooBaro();`. With two spaces, `void bar() =fooBaroo();`

issues.title: Automatic build doesn't work when source folder is more than one directory deep

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1662 : Automatic build doesn't work when source folder is more than
one directory deep.

Fix #1662 : Automatic build doesn't work when source folder is more than
one directory deep.

issues.body:
By default, the Ceylon source directory is "source" and the automatic build in Eclipse (compile on save) works fine (I can set the verbosity level to "all" and see the debug output of Ceylon doing the compilation).

I can add additional source directories that are one level deep (e.g., "source2") and the automatic build in Eclipse works for them also.

However, if I add a source directory that is more than one level deep (e.g., "other/source"), the automatic build does not work on the source directories that are more than one level deep (i.e., it keeps working on the other source directories but not on the deeper ones).

This is a problem because the automatic build does not work when using a Maven-style source directory of "src/main/ceylon" in a Maven project.

issues.title: IDE does not display any documentation when hovering vert.x APIs

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
IDE does not display any documentation when hovering vert.x APIs (#1660)

Fix it on the `1.2.1-preparation` branch also.

issues.body:
Vert.x does the right thing and encodes documentation using `@DocAnnotation$annotation$`, but the IDE just refuses to display it. This is _terrible_, since it means there is simply no way to view the documentation for any vert.x APIs.

@davidfestal what's your take on this?

issues.title: NPE when visiting annotations with default arguments

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1627 (NPE when visiting annotations with default arguments):

take in account a possible `UnresolvedReferenceBinding` when
constructing a `JDTType`

Fix #1627 (NPE when visiting annotations with default arguments):

take in account a possible `UnresolvedReferenceBinding` when
constructing a `JDTType`

issues.body:
This looks like it is a bug in the typechecker, but it only happens in Eclipse, not from the CLI so I think the real problem is in the JDT model.

Steps to reproduce:
- create a new project with a new module like this:

``` ceylon
native("jvm")
module mymodule "1.0.0" {
    shared import ceylon.net "1.2.0-2";
}
```
- create a new fancy annotation like this one:

``` ceylon
import ceylon.language.meta.declaration {
    ClassDeclaration
}
import ceylon.net.http {
    get,
    AbstractMethod
}

shared annotation RouteAnnotation route(String path, AbstractMethod meth = get)
        => RouteAnnotation(path, meth);

shared final annotation class RouteAnnotation(String path, {AbstractMethod*} meth)
        satisfies OptionalAnnotation<RouteAnnotation, ClassDeclaration> {}

route("/")
class Foo() {}
```

Note that we can omit the second argument when we call `route()` on class `Foo`, everything works fine.
- create a second project, with its own module that imports the first module, then create a new annotated class:

```
import mymodule {
    route
}

route("/")
class Foo() {}
```

Clean build the project, this will generate an error: 

```
the 'ExpressionVisitor' caused an exception visiting a 'Annotation' node: '"java.lang.NullPointerException"' at 'com.redhat.ceylon.model.loader.AbstractModelLoader.getPackageNameForQualifiedClassName(AbstractModelLoader.java:664)'
```

The full stack trace is here:

```
java.lang.NullPointerException
    at com.redhat.ceylon.model.loader.AbstractModelLoader.getPackageNameForQualifiedClassName(AbstractModelLoader.java:664)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.JDTModelLoader.findModuleForClassMirror(JDTModelLoader.java:1701)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.model.loader.AbstractModelLoader.convertDeclaredTypeToDeclaration(AbstractModelLoader.java:577)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.model.loader.AbstractModelLoader.convertNonPrimitiveTypeToDeclaration(AbstractModelLoader.java:542)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.model.loader.AbstractModelLoader.getNonPrimitiveType(AbstractModelLoader.java:4910)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.model.loader.AbstractModelLoader.obtainType(AbstractModelLoader.java:4814)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.java.loader.AnnotationLoader.readObjectValuesAnnotation(AnnotationLoader.java:350)

issues.title: Run the "Preparing completions" task in a background thread.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Globally make completion non-blocking.

For #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a background thread)

Fixes also:
- #1814 : Very slow auto-completion work
- #1815 : Double dots

There were 2 main problems:

- the UI was frozen because we had to construct completions in another
thread, and run the `Display` event loop manually while waiting for the
result.
Doing this now allows registering a document-change listener that
cancels the completion search as soon as some new text is typed in the
editor.

- the images should not be retrieved during the completion construction
(this can causes a dead-lock), but lazily when
`CompletionProposal.getImage()` is called.

Additionally, this commit also enables retrieving partial fast
completion results when in auto-activation mode, or when a build is
running. Each time a partial completion result is returned, a warning is
shown in the status bar.

Add a progress bar and fix second level management

In the context of #1589

Don't show a popup when exceptions occur during background completion

In the context of #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a
background thread.)

Final reword or non-blocking completion

In the context of #1589

Correctly import and override `org.eclipse.core.jobs`

in the context #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a
background thread)

Set busy cursor during the completion search and don't display the
result window if the text was changed in the meantime.

In the context of #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a
background thread)

Fix some bugs related to incorrect proposals ...

... due to the typechecking cancellation.

In the context of #1589

issues.body:
Currently, when you invoke code completion in a project that has huge dependencies, it can take a while before the popup appears. The IDE is completely frozen while it is preparing completions. It would be nice if we could continue typing while stuff is being computed in the background.

Also, it is currently not possible to stop this preparation, the red square is useless because it keeps computing things after you click it.

issues.title: IDE broken after the move of ceylon metadata annotations
issues.body: The annotations cannot be correctly read, because they are in the model  jar, which is not added by default in the Java project classpath. This produces all sort of errors during the build.

issues.title: Module conflict error crashes FatJar packaging tool

commitsDetails.commitMessage: fix #1863 add --force to fat jar args

issues.body:
From the command line, a module conflict results in...
```
Module org.slf4j:slf4j-api has multiple versions loaded: 1.6.4, 1.7.21 (use "--force" to select latest version 1.7.21)
ceylon fat-jar: Module conflict error prevented classpath generation: try
running "ceylon info --print-overrides app/1.0.0" to display an override file
you can use with "ceylon classpath --overrides override.xml app/1.0.0" or try
with "ceylon classpath --force app/1.0.0" to select the latest versions
```
But from within Eclipse the same conflict results in...
![fatjar tool crash](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7098161/21608800/a10edff2-d18c-11e6-82ad-d00f43c04455.png)

issues.title: NPE with SAMs

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1860 (NPE with SAMs):

I couldn't reproduce the problem, but at least I catch the exception
(that comes from JDT) correctly in the `JDTModelLoader`, and log a
precise message with the type name. That will allow reproducing and
debugging the problem more easily if it reappears.

issues.body:
```
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.jobs 4 2 2016-11-23 13:24:04.500
!MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Items filtering".
!STACK 0

issues.title: Completion popup not showing automatically when I type letters
issues.body:
On a simple hello world module, I enabled "Auto-activate completion proposal list", set it to "both" with a delay of "1ms". When I type a period, the popup is shown, but it doesn't work when I type letters.

When typing the following code:

```ceylon
shared void coin() {
	1.a
}
```

`and` and `absolute` should be shown automatically, but I have to explicitly call ctrl-space to show the popup.

issues.title: Annotation processors don't work inside the Eclipse plugin

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
for #1854 (annotation processors don't work):

also register the overriden Javac components (task listener, model
loader, compiler delegate) into the Javac context during each annotation
processor round (which create a new Language compiler each time)

issues.body:
The Eclipse plugin uses an overridden Java backend compiler (in order to reuse the already typechecked model), and the changes made in the Java backend to support annotation processing rounds also required some changes in the eclipse Plugin / Java backend integration.
So currently annotation processors don't work correctly in the Eclipse plugin on Ceylon projects.

commitsDetails.commitMessage: Navigation to members of Java annotations (fixes #1848).

issues.title: npm modules not downloaded on incremental build
issues.body: Just adding an `npm:` import to the module descriptor is not enough to trigger installation of the module. You need to do a Clean build to force it to occur.

issues.title: error with IntStream

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1844 (error with IntStream)


THis was due to the fact that the JDT model loader names the parameters
of Java methods according to their type. So the parameter was named
`int`, which led to an error in the backend since this is a Java
reserved keyword. I changed to prefix the parameter names with `_`.

issues.body:
I'm testing this code:

``` ceylon
IntStream.range(0, 10).forEach((i) => print(i^2));
```

Apart from ceylon/ceylon-ide-common#87, I get a second error in Eclipse:

> Ceylon backend error: cannot find symbol
>  symbol: variable int

This one doesn't occur in the CLI, nor in IntelliJ, AFAICT.

    import "npm:express" "4.0.0";

issues.title: Ceylon Explorer broken
issues.body: It seems that the `CeylonExplorer` is broken and, on some projects, doesn't show any child.

issues.title: NPE creating source folder in compiler-js project
issues.body:

issues.title: Changes in a dependency project are not detected
issues.body:
I have both ide-common and ide-eclipse open. If I remove a formal function from `DocGenerator`, save then go delete the actual declaration in `EclipseDocGenerator`, it does not see the changes I made in ide-common and complains that `Formal member getUnitName of DocGenerator not implemented in class hierarchy`. I have to clean build both projects to remove the error.
- I didn't change my project setup recently, and ide-eclipse still has a dependency to ide-common
- "build automatically" is enabled

issues.title: autocompletion inside expression case
issues.body: Autocompletion inside a `case` condition of a `switch` expression is broken.

issues.title: Cross-project dependencies to Java sources incorrectly tracked

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1790: Cross-project dependencies to Java sources incorrectly
tracked.

issues.body: If I modify a class of a Java source file in a Ceylon project, and this class is used in a depending Ceylon project, the files that depend on this class in the depending project are not rebuilt.

issues.title: Unit test view and peformance

commitsDetails.commitMessage: specifying ceylon testview refresh interval via system property #1788

issues.body: I have another - very reproducible - performance issue: Eclipse with a visible ceylon unit test view constantly eats 1/2 core, independent of the presence or volume of unit test results. As soon as I close or hide the view, eclipse drops to zero CPU usage, only to creep up when opening/showing it. I did not observe such behaviour with other views.

}

issues.title: Ceylon classpath containers should be exported by default
issues.body: If a Java project depends on a Ceylon project, it needs the classpath containers to be exported. There's _no way_ that any user is ever going to realize that, so they should be exported by default.

issues.title: Eclipse performance (with better info)
issues.body:
With the eclipse UI responsivity diagnosis and some luck, I was able to pinpoint two things.

First, I am reliably unable to switch panels in the eclipse preferences while a ceylon program is running from the IDE. As soon as the program stops, I see the new preferences page. Not even minimizing the main UI solves the block, which helped in many other occassions.

While the use case is admittedly weak, the contention that causes the delay it is likely to be a major driver for #1706. I hope this is reproducible somewhere.

Then, I got served an interesting stack trace / frame:

```
at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.code.navigator.CeylonNavigatorLabelProvider.getImage(CeylonNavigatorLabelProvider.java:257)
```

This seems to be a very expensive fall-back path; I actually got three of these during a 7 second outage (according to the UI responsiveness tooling; I could swear they miss half the fun).

The net effect seems to be a trawl through all .cars and probably more during the LinkEditorAction - i.e. on the UI thread. I'm not an expert on this topic but I'm certain there is room for improvement.

issues.title: Rename refactoring places ill-fomed imports with keyword package names

commitsDetails.commitMessage: fix #1765 handle escaped package names in rename package

issues.body:
If I rename packages (with subpackages) that have keyword sub-packages, the new imports are illegal.

E.g. a.x -> a.y leads a.x.out to become a.y.out, but imports and package declarations of that identifier are not protected (a.y.\iout). In fact they become a.y.outut in some places, probably because the protection which was there before is not being accounted for.

issues.title: initializer annotation and highlight range are completely broken
issues.body: `AdditionalAnnotationCreator` is busted :-(

issues.title: mangled identifier with rename refactoring
issues.body:
If you have an unsaved file, rename refactoring may not work correctly.

Start with the files below, saved:

`fileA.ceylon`:

``` ceylon
void foo() {}
```

`fileB.ceylon`:

``` ceylon
void bar() => foo();
```

Then:
1. Add a space character before `void bar` in `fileB.ceylon`, so that there will be unsaved changes
2. CMD-Option-R on `fileA.ceylon`'s `foo`. Rename to `fooBar`
3. Click "OK" in the "Save Modified Resources" dialog that will appear

The result in `fileB.ceylon` will be `void bar() =>fooBaro();`. With two spaces, `void bar() =fooBaroo();`

issues.title: navigation to methods of ide-common "nodes" from Java

commitsDetails.commitMessage: Fix #1747 (navigation to methods of ide-common "nodes" from Java)

issues.body: When I try to navigate to any of the methods of `nodes` from within the Java code of the IDE, I get taken to the Java editor instead of the Ceylon editor.

issues.title: refinement completions and qualified parameter types
refinement completions and overloading in Java
completion of qualified types inside "case (is X.Y)"
issues.body: Attempting to complete `case (is X.Y)` is impossible.

issues.title: Extract Function does not handle inherited members correctly
issues.body: References to inherited members aren't treated as local refs by Extract Function. They should be.

issues.title: problem with Java 8 default methods
issues.body: In the IDE, ceylon-sdk has a compile error in `ceylon.interop.java::JavaIterator`, because `remove()` refines a Java `default` method, and the model loader doesn't know what to do with that yet.

issues.title: wrong icon for see links in doc hover
issues.body: In the doc hover, `see` links are rendered with an exclamation mark, which is the icon for an _exception_. It should be the little chain-link icon.

issues.title: Find References / Find Assignments and shortcut refinement

commitsDetails.commitMessage: fix #1735 handle shortcut refinement correctly for Find Assign/Refer

issues.title: "invert if/else statement" assist is broken
IDE no longer respects linked mode preferences
issues.body: There is a preferences screen that lets you turn off the use of linked mode with refactorings. The IDE currently ignores these preferences, at least on master.

issues.title: navigation broken within conditions
issues.body: Given `if (is Tree.Body node)`, if I click on `node`, it should take me to the _original_ definition of `node`. I'm sure that used to work.

issues.title: problem with quick fix in unsaved editor
issues.body:
If I have this code in an _unsaved_ editor:

``` ceylon

class Foo(String text) {
    if (1==1) {
        void print() => print(text);
    }
}

issues.title: NPE using stale "Ceylon Type Hierarchy"
issues.body:
I've repeated this process twice:

1) Use F4 to populate the Ceylon Type Hierarchy
2) Edit one of the classes
3) Save
4) Click on another class in the hierarchy. An error dialog appears reporting a NPE.

At this point, NPEs happen when clicking on _most_ of the nodes (clicking on Anything, Object, and Basic do not result in exceptions.)

issues.title: error editing '.ceylon' file in non-Ceylon project

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Allow back the editing of Ceylon files in non-Ceylon projects

ceylon/ceylon-ide-eclipse#1675

issues.body:
Opening and saving `x.ceylon` files in a non-Ceylon project results in an error dialog with:

```
An internal error occurred during: "Parsing and typechecking dartExtras.ceylon".
Assertion failed
    violated exists existingCeylonProject = ceylonModel.getProject(nativeResource.project)
```

This project very similar to the `ceylon/language`, with an identical `.project` config, but for some reason I'm only seeing this error in my project. Perhaps the difference is that in the project with errors, the Ceylon source files are in a `source` directory, as opposed to `src` for the `ceylon.language` project.

My project's config is:

``` xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<projectDescription>
        <name>ceylon-dart-language</name>
        <comment></comment>
        <projects>
        </projects>
        <buildSpec>
                <buildCommand>
                        <name>org.eclipse.jdt.core.javabuilder</name>
                        <arguments>
                        </arguments>
                </buildCommand>
        </buildSpec>
        <natures>
                <nature>org.eclipse.jdt.core.javanature</nature>
        </natures>
</projectDescription>
```

_Edit_ corrected: I'm _only_ seeing this error in my project, not the dist one.

issues.title: Automatic build doesn't work when source folder is more than one directory deep

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1662 : Automatic build doesn't work when source folder is more than
one directory deep.

Fix #1662 : Automatic build doesn't work when source folder is more than
one directory deep.

issues.body:
By default, the Ceylon source directory is "source" and the automatic build in Eclipse (compile on save) works fine (I can set the verbosity level to "all" and see the debug output of Ceylon doing the compilation).

I can add additional source directories that are one level deep (e.g., "source2") and the automatic build in Eclipse works for them also.

However, if I add a source directory that is more than one level deep (e.g., "other/source"), the automatic build does not work on the source directories that are more than one level deep (i.e., it keeps working on the other source directories but not on the deeper ones).

This is a problem because the automatic build does not work when using a Maven-style source directory of "src/main/ceylon" in a Maven project.

issues.title: IDE does not display any documentation when hovering vert.x APIs

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
IDE does not display any documentation when hovering vert.x APIs (#1660)

Fix it on the `1.2.1-preparation` branch also.

issues.body:
Vert.x does the right thing and encodes documentation using `@DocAnnotation$annotation$`, but the IDE just refuses to display it. This is _terrible_, since it means there is simply no way to view the documentation for any vert.x APIs.

@davidfestal what's your take on this?

issues.title: NPE when visiting annotations with default arguments

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1627 (NPE when visiting annotations with default arguments):

take in account a possible `UnresolvedReferenceBinding` when
constructing a `JDTType`

Fix #1627 (NPE when visiting annotations with default arguments):

take in account a possible `UnresolvedReferenceBinding` when
constructing a `JDTType`

issues.body:
This looks like it is a bug in the typechecker, but it only happens in Eclipse, not from the CLI so I think the real problem is in the JDT model.

Steps to reproduce:
- create a new project with a new module like this:

``` ceylon
native("jvm")
module mymodule "1.0.0" {
    shared import ceylon.net "1.2.0-2";
}
```
- create a new fancy annotation like this one:

``` ceylon
import ceylon.language.meta.declaration {
    ClassDeclaration
}
import ceylon.net.http {
    get,
    AbstractMethod
}

shared annotation RouteAnnotation route(String path, AbstractMethod meth = get)
        => RouteAnnotation(path, meth);

shared final annotation class RouteAnnotation(String path, {AbstractMethod*} meth)
        satisfies OptionalAnnotation<RouteAnnotation, ClassDeclaration> {}

route("/")
class Foo() {}
```

Note that we can omit the second argument when we call `route()` on class `Foo`, everything works fine.
- create a second project, with its own module that imports the first module, then create a new annotated class:

```
import mymodule {
    route
}

route("/")
class Foo() {}
```

Clean build the project, this will generate an error: 

```
the 'ExpressionVisitor' caused an exception visiting a 'Annotation' node: '"java.lang.NullPointerException"' at 'com.redhat.ceylon.model.loader.AbstractModelLoader.getPackageNameForQualifiedClassName(AbstractModelLoader.java:664)'
```

The full stack trace is here:

```

issues.title: Run the "Preparing completions" task in a background thread.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Globally make completion non-blocking.

For #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a background thread)

Fixes also:
- #1814 : Very slow auto-completion work
- #1815 : Double dots

There were 2 main problems:

- the UI was frozen because we had to construct completions in another
thread, and run the `Display` event loop manually while waiting for the
result.
Doing this now allows registering a document-change listener that
cancels the completion search as soon as some new text is typed in the
editor.

- the images should not be retrieved during the completion construction
(this can causes a dead-lock), but lazily when
`CompletionProposal.getImage()` is called.

Additionally, this commit also enables retrieving partial fast
completion results when in auto-activation mode, or when a build is
running. Each time a partial completion result is returned, a warning is
shown in the status bar.

Add a progress bar and fix second level management

In the context of #1589

Don't show a popup when exceptions occur during background completion

In the context of #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a
background thread.)

Final reword or non-blocking completion

In the context of #1589

Correctly import and override `org.eclipse.core.jobs`

in the context #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a
background thread)

Set busy cursor during the completion search and don't display the
result window if the text was changed in the meantime.

In the context of #1589 (Run the "Preparing completions" task in a
background thread)

Fix some bugs related to incorrect proposals ...

... due to the typechecking cancellation.

In the context of #1589

issues.body:
Currently, when you invoke code completion in a project that has huge dependencies, it can take a while before the popup appears. The IDE is completely frozen while it is preparing completions. It would be nice if we could continue typing while stuff is being computed in the background.

Also, it is currently not possible to stop this preparation, the red square is useless because it keeps computing things after you click it.

issues.title: Declarations are not found after upgrade to 1.2.0
issues.body:
I recently cleaned my local repo because I had dev modules tagged 1.2.0 and wanted to download the final builds from Herd. I deleted every folder named `1.2.0` in `~/.ceylon/repo`.

Then I went back to eclipse, and ceylon-ide-common wouldn't build anymore: some dependencies were not found in the local repo, for example `ceylon.interop.java 1.2.0`. The CLI could compile the project, because it downloaded dependencies in `~/.ceylon/cache`, but it looks like Eclipse only looks for dependencies in `repo`, not `cache`. 

What's strange is that I can ctrl-click on the package `ceylon.interop.java` and it will bring me to the correct `module.ceylon` in `~/.ceylon/cache/.../ceylon.interop.java-1.2.src!/...`, but somehow declarations in that package can't be found.

I built the dist and the SDK, which put all the necessary dependencies in `~/.ceylon/repo` and everything went back to normal.

Note: the checkbox "work offline" is not enabled in ceylon-ide-common.

"Cannot complete the install because one or more required items could not be found. Software being installed: Ceylon IDE 1.2.0.v20151028-2224-Final (com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.feature.feature.group 1.2.0.v20151028-2224-Final)
 Missing requirement: Ceylon IDE 1.2.0.v20151028-2224-Final (com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.feature.feature.group 1.2.0.v20151028-2224-Final)  requires ‘org.eclipse.zest.feature.group 1.5.0' but it could not be found"

Installing Zest using the update site: http://download.eclipse.org/tools/gef/updates/releases/ fixed the problem. I used Eclipse Mars for Java Developper.

Regards

issues.title: JS Backend NPE on JVM maven imports
issues.body:
This is Eclipse specific.

For a dual backend project with nothing but `module.ceylon`:

``` ceylon
module simple "1.0.0" {
    native("jvm") import java.base "7";
    native("jvm") import "com.google.guava:guava" "18.0";
}
```

There are two error markers on the `guava` import:

```
the '' caused an exception visiting a 'ImportModule' node:
'"java.lang.NullPointerException"'
at 'com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.js.JsCompiler$1.visit(JsCompiler.java:265)'
```

The same happens for `native("jvm") import "log4j:log4j" "1.2.17";`

issues.title: pass generated code through formatter in Paste Java as Ceylon

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Paste Java as correctly indented Ceylon

Detect indentation of current line and use that as initial indentation
for formatter. Reported by @bjansen in #1532.

issues.body: Paste Java as Ceylon produces code with the indentation all screwed up.

issues.title: errors shown in outline of StringBuilder
issues.body: When I open `ceylon.language::StringBuilder` in the IDE, I see lots of errors in the outline. This is a regression. @davidfestal how did you fix this last time?

issues.title: With the Hierarchical view, source folders don't always appear at the top
issues.body:
After updating to the latest build, I noticed source folders within Ceylon projects appearing in alphabetical order in the Ceylon explorer, rather than floating to the top as they should.

_But_, after toggling settings in "Customize View..." -> "Content", the source folders did start appearing at the top.

I'm not sure yet if this is a one time setup issue, or an intermittent problem.

See also a few notes starting https://github.com/ceylon/ceylon-ide-eclipse/issues/1238#issuecomment-147628747.

issues.title: Unit tests: Inconsistent results when combining native and non-native unit tests in the same file

commitsDetails.commitMessage: ceylon.test: don't show native implementation in ui #1527

issues.body:
Write the following unit test in a Ceylon project that supports JVM and JS:

It may be necessary to rename the non-native unit test or move its relative position in the file to reproduce this. 

``` ceylon
import ceylon.test {
    test,
    assertTrue
}

native
test
shared void crossPlatformTest();

native("jvm")
test
shared void crossPlatformTest() { assertTrue(true); }

native("js")
test
shared void crossPlatformTest() { assertTrue(false); }

test
shared void normalTest() {assertTrue(true);}
```

Sometimes both unit tests will be executed and sometimes only one will be executed.    Repeated executions with different ordering will be necessary to reproduce this because it's totally inconsistent and I can't find the determining factor.  The unit test that's left out is not consistent either.  Sometimes it's the native unit test, sometimes it's the non-native unit test.

I could not reproduce this at all from the command line (JVM or JavaScript), which is why I'm filing it under ceylon-ide-eclipse.

issues.title: eGit diff fails and SWT exception with latest Ceylon IDE
issues.body:
Not sure if this is a showstopper for 1.2.

This was working on the Ceylon IDE I built recently before.

1) Sync from the github projects and rebuild ceylon-ide-eclipse and update Eclipse
2) Import a Ceylon github project you have commit rights to (this will probably work for a forked project)
3) Make a change to a Ceylon file.
4) Open the Git Staging View
5) Double-click the Ceylon file to show the diff

The diff window will be blank even if there are changes running git diff from the command line.

Here's what I see in the Error Log view (the caused by NullPointerException starts with com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.JDTModuleManager.getSupportedBackends):

Currently, the backend Java binary generation (during the build), doesn't take in account several compiler-reated options such as `noosgi`, `resourceroot`, etc ...

This can result in the generated binary archive being different between the CLI and the IDE.

issues.title: shared unit test Run As > Ceylon Test Java Script does nothing
issues.body:
1) Create an Eclipse project that supports Java and JavaScript
2) Write a very simple unit test

``` ceylon
import ceylon.test {
    assertTrue,

}

test
shared void testMe() {
    assertTrue(true);
}
```

```
NODE_PATH=${ECLIPSE_HOME}/plugins/com.redhat.ceylon.dist.repo_1.1.1.v20151005-1936/repo:${WORKSPACE_HOME}/JavaAndJavaScript/modules:${HOME}/.ceylon/repo:${HOME}/.ceylon/cache:[Maven] Aether:${WORKSPACE_HOME}/JavaAndJavaScript/modules

issues.title: "Setting up typechecker" phase hangs and can't be cancelled

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1517 : this contains an optimization that might also globally
increase the build performance by greatly reduce the number of times we
search for secondary types.
`JDTModelLoader` optimizations following the work made for #1517

issues.body:
OK, this is just incredibly painful. If the "Setting up typechecker" job hangs while trying to retrieve a dependency:
- the build it can't be canceled,
- the job holds a hard lock on the whole project

What this means is that I have to stop the whole process to recover from this. 

This is especially bad b/c recently I've been getting hands pretty regularly here. We need to fix it.

issues.title: Code completion performance issues in ceylon-ide-intellij
issues.body:
The first time completion is called, these two hotspots can be seen in yourkit:
- a [call to `org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaElement.exists()`](https://github.com/ceylon/ceylon-ide-eclipse/blob/master/plugins/com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.ui/src/com/redhat/ceylon/eclipse/core/model/JDTModelLoader.java#L376) takes ~ 40% of the total time
- a [call to `org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.ClassFile.getBinaryTypeInfo(IFile, boolean)`](https://github.com/ceylon/ceylon-ide-eclipse/blob/master/plugins/com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.ui/src/com/redhat/ceylon/eclipse/core/model/JDTModelLoader.java#L1126) takes ~ 60% of the total time

These two methods ultimately spend most of their time opening zip files (FTR `idea.jar` is approximately 125MB).

The second time completion is called, the hotspots change:
- approx. 45% of the total time is spent in `com.redhat.ceylon.model.typechecker.model.Declaration.equals(Object)`, called by [Package.getMatchingDeclarations()](https://github.com/ceylon/ceylon-model/blob/master/src/com/redhat/ceylon/model/typechecker/model/Package.java#L233)

See [this yourkit snapshot](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B8u_iEp6ftT7b0s0Q2xPTlJ4SDQ/view?usp=sharing) for more details of the second run.

issues.title: Test comparison window uses wrong encoding
issues.body: In the `ceylon.test` comparison window, all my `’`s (U+2019 RIGHT SINGLE QUOTATION MARK) look like this: `â` (![screenshot from 2015-09-28 19-12-05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2346599/10142764/d9f2915e-6614-11e5-8876-0974634d7a91.png)). This is what you get if you interpret UTF-8 ’ (e2 80 99) as ISO 8859-1 (e2 is â, 80 and 99 are unassigned). I’m not sure why the test window chose ISO 8859-1 (my platform’s default encoding should be UTF-8), but it should probably use the encoding of the project (from the Ceylon config).

issues.title: Incremental compilation of SDK includes unchanged modules
issues.body:
I'm using `Eclipse Mars 4.5.0` with `Ceylon IDE 1.1.1.v20150721-1337-Final`.

When I save any change (even just a whitespace change) to a [ceylon.net.http.client](https://github.com/ASzc/ceylon-sdk/tree/http-rewrite/source/ceylon/net/http/client) source file in the SDK project, and then save it, a long (>10 seconds) compilation step follows. This appears in the Progress tab, and will block subsequent save operations until it completes.

I would expect that a few files in the current module might need to be recompiled, but it seems that files in unrelated modules (such as ceylon.collection) are being recompiled as well.

I've tried to get a succinct log of this activity, but the best I have been able to find is the "code" log level for the compiler. Since GitHub won't let me attach the file, I have put it temporarily [here](http://szc.ca/ceylon-ide-log_code_2015-09-27.txt.gz).

issues.title: Typechecker errors are removed when using native("js")
issues.body:
I created a new project, enabled both "Compile for JVM" and "Compile for Javascript", then created two modules:
- one is annotated `native("js")`
- one is annotated `native("jvm")`

In the JS module, typechecker errors are not reported. This leads to the JS backend being invoked, and the compilation succeeds: I can run my code in the browser although the Ceylon code is incorrect. This only happens in the IDE.

Example of invalid code, for which no typechecker error is reported:

```
void fun(dynamic foo, Lololol lol) { // note the invalid type Lololol
    print(foo); // this shouldn't work because foo is dynamic
}
```

issues.title: unjustified encoding error during rename refactoring with encoding CP1252
issues.body:
First, this is minor because the workaround is simply to switch to UTF-8 instead of CP1252. But CP1252 is the default for an Eclipse project on Windows.

To reproduce :
- Set your Ceylon project encoding to CP1252
- Then create this class

``` ceylon
class Location(unLocode, String simpleName) {
    shared String unLocode;
    shared String name => simpleName + " (" + unLocode + ")";
}
```

And try to inline rename (`Shift+Alt+R`) the class parameter `simpleName` to `simpleName2`

issues.title: suppressWarnings("unusedDeclaration") not working
issues.body:
I have just spent an hour or so trying to chase this one down and I got as far as seeing that `UsageWarning`s are _not_ marked `suppressed` when `MarkerCreator` is called from `CeylonBuilder.addProblemAndTaskMarkers()`.

That's _really_ super-weird because on the line right before, we visit the tree using a `WarningSuppressionVisitor`. So for some reason, `WarningSuppressionVisitor` is not doing it's job in this case.

It _does_ work in the case of `AnnotationCreator`, which makes it doubly-weird.

issues.title: Correctly synchronize the parse controller typechecking

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
fix second bug related to #1461
some reformatting

#1478 : make a specific getter for returning to possible-non-typechecked
root node. This simply avoids having to do a synchronization,since the
rootNode available through `getRootNode()` is always fully typechecked.

#1478 : use the more recently parsed root node, even if not typechecked
(we don't use the model in `TerminateStatemementAction`)

#1478 : correctly doument and rename CPC getters, add a way to retrieve
the most recent root node only if typechecked (or null), and use it in
refactorings.

#1478 : attemp to use the right CPC rootNode getter for all the other
existing calls of CPC.getLastCompilationUnit()
#1478 : Choose the right root node for quick fixes and quick assists

issues.body:
Now that the typechecking performed inside the `CeylonParseController` isn't synchronized anymore by the `Workspace` scheduling rule, it seems that regularly the `unit` of some AST nodes is found to be `null`, which cause NPEs at various places. 

We should find a way to avoid this without reintroducing the previous synchronization that was a cause of deadlock (#1412).

For example, see : 
- https://github.com/ceylon/ceylon-ide-eclipse/commit/5356a58d6abe8d768a5fc20bd289407ec9444303#commitcomment-13051207
- #1461

issues.title: Add imports when pasting code
issues.body:
IIRC, until two or three months ago, imports would automatically be added as necessary when copying and pasting code from one file to another.

For example, in a project without errors, copying and pasting:

``` ceylon
value l = ArrayList<String>();
```

would add

``` ceylon
import ceylon.collection {
    ArrayList
}
```

if necessary.

```
/project/source/p1/run.ceylon
/Users/gavin/Documents/runtime-EclipseApplication/project/modules/p1/1.0.0/module1-1.0.0.src!/module1/run.ceylon
```

The match in the temp source archive should be suppressed, I believe.

@davidfestal would you take a look at this please?

issues.title: Extract Value expression suggestions
issues.body:
Try Extract Value on:

``` ceylon
Boolean balanced(String input)
        => !input
            .map((ch) => switch (ch) case('[') 1 case (']') -1 else 0)
            .scan(0)(plus)
            .any(Integer.negative);
```

You get rubbish expression suggestions.

issues.title: Refine formal members quick assist much worse after change to FindNodeVisitor
issues.body: `FindNodeVisitor` has started returning statements that the caret is not inside of. That has broken the behavior of the refine formal members quick assist, which used to be able to add the refined members at the caret position, but can't anymore, even with the bugfix I just committed.

issues.title: lots of new bugs in Rename refactoring
issues.body:
OK, so Rename is now a big mess. (Not really anybody's fault, since there were no tests, of course.)

Things I've noticed:
1. In `x.member`, placing the caret right between `x` and `.` and hitting ⌘⌥R selects `member` for renaming instead of `x`. (This may be due to the changes to `FindNodeVisitor`.)
2. Very often, selecting a usage of a local variable, and hitting ⌘⌥R selects the usage for renaming, but does not select the actual definition.

This needs to go through a full retest / bugfix process.

issues.title: NPE when renaming module
issues.body: Check out https://github.com/ceylon/ceylon.tool.converter.java2ceylon, select its main module, then right-click on `Refactor > Rename` and change its name. You will get LOTS of NPEs in the backend when the build is done. Wait about 30 seconds, then they're gone and all is green.

issues.title: CCE `Retrieving Fixes` MethodDeclaration vs SwitchStatement
issues.body:
with this (erroneous) code, hover over `switch` with the mouse cursor

``` ceylon
shared String foo(Integer bar) => switch (bar)
```

you get
`An internal error occurred during: "Retrieving Fixes". com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.typechecker.tree.CustomTree$MethodDeclaration cannot be cast to com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.typechecker.tree.Tree$SwitchStatement`

issues.title: renaming member of object expression broken
Unsupported declaration type: unknown

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
#1445 : don't popup an error in this case, since for any file with an
exception the delta-based filtering won't be applied.

issues.title: Cannot save new formatting options
issues.body:
1. Open properties for a project
2. `Ceylon Code Formatter`/`New`
3. Give the new profile a name, click `OK`
4. `OK` to close "Modify Formatter Profile" dialog
5. `OK` to close properties dialog
6. Discover that the bug no longer occurs despite it happening two times in a row before
7. File a bug report anyway.

At step 4 or 5, (maybe with a slightly different procedure?) a dialog with the following appeared:

> An error has occurred. See error log for more details.
> ceylon/formatter/options/unlimited (wrong name: ceylon/formatter/options/Unlimited)

issues.title: Formatting fails silently for last declaration in file

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1443

findNode() now takes an additional token list (see
ceylon/ceylon-ide-common@5d509a0 for details), which we have to pass in
lots of places. Most of the time, we can get it from the
CeylonParseController; occasionally, we just pass null. (That's not
necessarily bad: for example, we don't have to worry about whitespace in
the selection when the selection comes from an error marker.)

issues.title: Incremental Build regression
issues.body: The fix for https://github.com/ceylon/ceylon-ide-eclipse/issues/1412 has reintroduced an incremental build bug in which the model caches are changed by the typechecking that occurs inside the `CeylonParseController`, so that, afterwards, some declarations are not found anymore when classes of a referenced project are changed.

issues.title: supertype hierarchy only goes one level deep
issues.body: Possibly related to #1427, the supertypes mode is missing supertypes of inherited interfaces!

issues.title: navigation from supertype hierarchy is broken
issues.body: In both the popup and the view, clicking on a type in the supertype mode does not take me to the type.

issues.title: Missing native headers in binary-loaded declaration brings errors in archive files

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
#1425 : fix it by pretending that the SingleSourceUnitPackage has a
`jvm` scope.

issues.body:
the typechecking of binary archive ceylon files opened in the CeylonEditor sometimes produces the following error in the AST : 

```
+  [BaseMemberExpression] (156:48-156:51) : true : true : value true => true [X][non-native declaration: 'anonymous#1' accesses native code: 'true', mark it or the module native]
|  + true [Identifier] (156:48-156:51)
|  +  [InferredTypeArguments]
```

This adds error decorators in the outline of such files.

It's related to the fact that the header is not available in the central model for binary-loaded declarations

#1421 : Bring the `getSourceXXX()` methods to the `IdeUnit` level.
#1421 : Add the Java class file icon to plugin icons

issues.body:
If I run Find References on Iterable.sequence() I get:
- a bunch of bogus matches from `ceylon.language - /Users/gavin/Documents/workspace/.metadata/.plugins/com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.ui/JavaSourceArchiveCache/Users/gavin/.ceylon/repo/ceylon.language-1.1.1.javaSources.zip`, and
- depending where I am when I run it, a bunch of additional bogus matches in `.class` files in a totally weird and broken-looking module named `ceylon.language_1.1.1` in the project `com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.ui`.

@davidfestal these bugs could be mine, but they look suspiciously like they have to do with your modularity stuff. Would you take a look, please?

issues.title: CCE "Retrieving Fixes"
issues.body:
create a shortcut method with this code:

``` ceylon
    shared actual Comparison compare(Jogadas other) =>
        switch (other)
        case (tesoura) 
            smaller; //Intentional, some syntar error
        case (papel) 
            equal
        case (pedra) 
            larger
```

and put mouse hover `switch` word..

Result:

``` ceylon
An internal error occurred during: "Retrieving Fixes".
com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.typechecker.tree.CustomTree$MethodDeclaration cannot be cast to com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.typechecker.tree.Tree$SwitchStatement
```

issues.title: JS backend doesn't ignore module imports marked `native("jvm")`
issues.body:
I have a module with a descriptor like this:

``` ceylon
module foobar "1.0.0" {

}
```

issues.title: `hash/equals` refinement mistakes singleton c-tor for attributes
Move class/interface does not generate correct imports
Completion proposals retrieved in the UI thread in the `AnnotationInformationControl`

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
#1402 : Fix the NPE introduced by the previous fix : add an explicit
`CeylonEditor` parameter to the `LocalProposal` constructor.

issues.body:
In some case, the lookup of completion proposals can be a bit long (several seconds). So if many hovering events are triggered, this lookup is scheduled in the UI thread many times, which finally freezes the UI of Eclipse for a while.
This lookup should be done in a background thread, and the results should be added (inside a UI Thread) only if the information controller had not been dismissed in the meantime. And for performance this background lookup should be canceled  when the current hover is dismissed.

issues.title: Adapt to the last `native` changes

commitsDetails.commitMessage: #1401 : now require to explicitely check the declaration native backend

#1401 : fix incremental build for natives (and other corner cases
involving Java sources)

#1401 : overloads cleaning is not necessary anymore since header and
implementations are required to be in the same source file.

#1401 : Better management of source declaration that allow having
Java-implemented native implementations, even in Java-Javascript
projects.

#1401 : now we can remove the hack, since source archives native
declarations don't have these errors anymore.

issues.body:
- [x] incremental build : also rebuild units that contain some native-related errors (like what we do for files with `unknown declaration` errors
- [x] incremental build : clean the overload list on incremental build (in `ProjectPhasedUnit.remove()`)

issues.body:
I have two projects in my workspace: **A** is `ceylon-ide-common` and **B** is `plugin-ceylon-code` (the Ceylon code for the IntelliJ plugin). A has a dependency on B. 
- If I add a class or function in B, or modify a signature, the change is not visible in A unless I recompile using the CLI.
- If in project A I ctrl-click on a declaration located in B, it navigates to the source file in `~/.ceylon/repo/xyz.src` instead of the source file in project B.

Everything goes back to normal if in the project settings I change the system repo from `${user.home}/.ceylon/repo` to an empty value.

issues.title: error w/reserved words on dual-backend project
issues.body:
An error occurs when a dual backend project attempts to import a package that includes a Java reserved word:

``` ceylon
import mod1.long {
    parseLong // Cannot import Java declarations in Javascript
}
```

Attempting to use the import results in a similar error.

To reproduce:
1. Create a module `mod1` with a package `mod1.long`, and a function `mod1.long::parseLong()`. The package and function should of course be `shared`.
2. Install `mod1` in the local repository `~/.ceylon/repo` (be sure to include both JS and JVM binaries.
3. Create a module in a _different_ eclipse project, and attempt to import and use `mod1.long::parseLong()`.

No error occurs when the project in step 3 has only one backend enabled.

issues.title: debug breakpoints not working
Poor handling of non-existent annotation
issues.body:
If one writes
shared notthere void fooBar() {
 ...
}

The error generated by the compiler is:
"Function or value does not exist: notthere"
And it provides a quickfix to add an argument named notthere who's type is a Callable. This is an insane quickfix as it does not produce code that fixes the problem.

issues.title: Debug expression and type-parameters hovers broken
strange type error with type argument
Performance bottleneck when stepping into a function with defaulted arguments

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
Fix #1370 : don't use `IMethod.getParameterNames()` : it uses the
default JDT Source mapper, takes Ceyon code as being Java code, and
triggers a Java parsing of the ceylon code, which takes very long and of
course fails.

issues.body:
When `JavaSearch.getCeylonSimpleName()` tries to find the Ceylon mapping of the method with defaulted arguments generated in Java Bytecode, it triggers the JDT parsingon the corresponding Ceylon code, which of course generates all sort of errors internally, but without throwing them. This makes debugging these parts of code very long !
This was show by the Java Mission Control profiler immediately !

issues.body:
When debugging, an editor containing a source archive can be reused to step into another source archive. In this case, the content of the new source archive is _not_ parsed again.
This produces a weird situation, when hovers display information about the previous content of the editor.

issues.title: Default source folder is called `defaultSourceFolder`
issues.body:
Creating a new project will create a folder that’s literally called `defaultSourceFolder`. That’s a bit silly, it should just be `source`.

Possibly introduced in c99726aad5a161d205d4988648041501a1f24781. That commit seems to indicate that a resource folder would similarly be called `defaultResourceFolder`, but I haven’t tested that.

Previously, if I navigated to, for example, `Integer.plus`, the IDE would pop up a menu with two options, the Ceylon declaration, and the Java declaration. Now it takes me straight to Java.

@davidfestal do you have any clue what happened here? @quintesse is it something to do with your work on `native`?

issues.title: display errors generated by the JavaScript compiler
issues.body:
It would be nice if JS backend errors were indicated in the IDE.

For example, with today's build:

``` ceylon
print(9223372036854775808);
```

produces the following in the CLI:

```
$ ceylon compile-js
Error: Errors found. Compilation stopped.
Note: Created module simple/1.0.0
error encountered [literal outside representable range: 9223372036854775808 is too large to be represented as an Integer] at 54:10-54:28 of run.ceylon
ceylon compile-js: 1 errors.
```

but no indication of an error is available in the IDE. In _both_ cases, a module is created (despite the error), but due to the error, produces incorrect results at runtime.

Exception in the model Loader at initialization

commitsDetails.commitMessage: Fix #1322 : this was finally easier than expected

issues.body:
The followng exception is triggered during the classpath container initialization :

```
com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.loader.ModelResolutionException: The Model Loader corresponding to the type 'ceylon.language.$module_' was not available
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.JDTModelLoader.doWithReferenceBinding(JDTModelLoader.java:825)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.mirror.JDTClass.doWithBindings(JDTClass.java:382)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.mirror.JDTClass.getAnnotation(JDTClass.java:323)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.mirror.JDTClass.isAnnotationPresent(JDTClass.java:469)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.mirror.JDTClass.isCeylon(JDTClass.java:488)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.JDTModelLoader.newCompiledUnit(JDTModelLoader.java:1215)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.JDTModelLoader.setModuleAndPackageUnits(JDTModelLoader.java:1177)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.builder.CeylonBuilder$10.call(CeylonBuilder.java:2232)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.builder.CeylonBuilder$10.call(CeylonBuilder.java:1)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.builder.CeylonBuilder.doWithCeylonModelCaching(CeylonBuilder.java:249)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.builder.CeylonBuilder.parseCeylonModel(CeylonBuilder.java:2065)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.classpath.CeylonProjectModulesContainer.resolveClasspath(CeylonProjectModulesContainer.java:309)
    at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.classpath.InitDependenciesJob.run(InitDependenciesJob.java:51)
    at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:54)
```

This seems related to a race condition happening when many projects are opened.
It seems that the module descriptor class mirror retrieved during module validation for binary modules can sometimes come from another project that also contains this external archive. In this case, it might happen that the model loader of the other project is not already registered in the `JDTModelLoader` static loaders weak hash map.

issues.title: un-shared unit tests on JavaScript
issues.body:
Create a simple project with I have a simple JavaScript project in Eclipse with a simple unit test

``` ceylon

import ceylon.test {
    test,
    assertTrue
}

test
void testMe() {
    assertTrue(true);
}

```

This works if I compile the project and then run the unit test with the command line tools:

${PATH_TO_GITHUB_DIST}/bin/ceylon compile-js 
${PATH_TO_GITHUB_DIST}/bin/ceylon run-js luke.hellonodejs/1.1.1
${PATH_TO_GITHUB_DIST}/bin/ceylon test-js luke.hellonodejs/1.1.1

issues.title: Marker added twice for warnings reported by both the typechecker and the backend
Zest not installed automatically when installing from the update site
issues.body: Zest (which is part of the standard GEF 3 release and available on the main Eclipse update site), should be installed automatically when installing the plugin from the update site.

cross-project Java declarations not accessible when compiling in source-first mode
issues.body:
This already-existing but hidden bug, appeared after updating the `JDTModelLoader` according to the last changes in the `CeylonModelLoader`. It was reported by IDE tests.

In fact, a cross-project Ceylon module is not considered as being added to the classpath (since it is source), but it should still be, so that the modelLoader `isModuleOnClasspath()` method would return `true`.

This is now necessary after the change to `lookupNewClassMirror()` in commit 7d5cc5c00c5b223f4c1aee922fb15d9567480ae2.

issues.title: NPE when debugging is some Ceylon source code with the Expressions View opened

commitsDetails.commitMessage: #1301 : Check for obsolete filtered Java source archives.

#1301 : use cached filtered source archives that do not contain Ceylon
source file.

issues.body:
When debugging a Ceylon source file, if the Expressions View is opened and contains Java watches, this triggers a NPE with an error popup : 

```
java.lang.NullPointerException
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.SourceBasedSourceGenerator.getTypeName(SourceBasedSourceGenerator.java:783)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.SourceBasedSourceGenerator.buildMethodDeclaration(SourceBasedSourceGenerator.java:478)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.SourceBasedSourceGenerator.buildBody(SourceBasedSourceGenerator.java:419)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.SourceBasedSourceGenerator.buildTypeBody(SourceBasedSourceGenerator.java:360)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.SourceBasedSourceGenerator.buildTypeDeclaration(SourceBasedSourceGenerator.java:645)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.SourceBasedSourceGenerator.endVisit(SourceBasedSourceGenerator.java:1088)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.TypeDeclaration.accept0(TypeDeclaration.java:473)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTNode.accept(ASTNode.java:2711)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTNode.acceptChildren(ASTNode.java:2782)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.CompilationUnit.accept0(CompilationUnit.java:212)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.ASTNode.accept(ASTNode.java:2711)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.EvaluationSourceGenerator.createEvaluationSourceFromSource(EvaluationSourceGenerator.java:152)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.EvaluationSourceGenerator.getSource(EvaluationSourceGenerator.java:233)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.ASTEvaluationEngine.getCompiledExpression(ASTEvaluationEngine.java:319)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.ASTEvaluationEngine.evaluate(ASTEvaluationEngine.java:131)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.JavaWatchExpressionDelegate$EvaluationRunnable.run(JavaWatchExpressionDelegate.java:142)
    at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread$ThreadJob.run(JDIThread.java:3158)
    at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:54)
```

In fact the problem is that JDT doesn't look at the source file name to be sure this is Java code. and it tries to evaluate the watch expressions against the Ceylon source code, thinking it is Java code.
Since this pre-requisites are not met, finally a NPE is thrown.

It seems that the very root cause of this is that the Stratum in which the source file name and lines are added is the default stratum (ie. the Java stratum). This was also the real root cause of #1254.

@quintesse, @FroMage, @tombentley : Sometimes I think that, to avoid such bad surprises in the future, we should have used a `Ceylon` stratum to generate the `source name`, `source path` and all the debug information in the class files generated from Ceylon sources (and of course set the default stratum to `Ceylon` for those files).
See https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/jdk/api/jpda/jdi/com/sun/jdi/Location.html and https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/jdk/api/jpda/jdi/com/sun/jdi/ReferenceType.html#defaultStratum() for reference information about that.

This would be the best way to solve this issue.

issues.body:
If I attempt to implement:

``` ceylon
class MyMap satisfies Map<String->String, String> {
  ...
}
```

The IDE will auto generate the signature:

``` ceylon
    shared actual Iterator<String->String->String> iterator() => nothing;
```

Which is a compile error with the message:

```
Incorrect syntax: missing > operator at ->
```

But if I create a map and pass it the generic types `<String->String, String>` it says the return type of the `iterator()` method is: 

``` ceylon
 Iterator<String->String->String>
```

The correct signature would be:

``` ceylon
    shared actual Iterator<<String->String>->String> iterator() => nothing;
```

This also applies to the popup dialogs that show signatures.

issues.title: Breakpoints wrongly installed in files that have the same name.
issues.body:
if you set a breakpoint inside a `run` file of a project A, and debug another project B with a `run` file, the project B debug session will stop in the `run` file at the line of the breakpoint set in the `run` file of project A.
This is because we use `JavaStratumLineBreakpoint`s.

This is _very_ critical, since in Ceylon the source file name can often be the same across projects.

issues.title: Inter-project dependency bug
Incomplete results in OpenDeclarationDialog
issues.body:
If you have 2 projects in the IDE, and in project A `ceylon.collection` is imported _explicitly_, and in project  B `ceylon.collection` is transitively imported in a _non-shared_ way by some explicit dependency.  
In this case, the `JDTModule` object contained in the project B is **_not available_** and _does not contain any Package_, since in fact it is never seen (either directly or transitively) by the user code.

In the `OpenDeclarationDialog`, if this project B is considered before project A for the search, then all the declarations of module `ceylon.collection` will be skipped in the search results.

When using `Modules.getListOfModules()`, we should ensure that the `JDTModule` object is available with `isAvailable()`

issues.title: bug in model with inter-project dependencies
Module import quick fix imports java.auth when it should import ceylon.math
issues.body:
I've just started playing around with Ceylon and I ran into a bug that I didn't see reported when I looked through the open issues. 

Basically I was trying out the answer to [this stackoverflow question.](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28789422/why-would-you-create-an-iterable-instead-of-a-sequence-in-ceylon) But when I added the import statement there was an error because I didn't import the ceylon.math module in my module.ceylon file. When I hovered over it it offered to "quick fix" it by importing the "java.auth" module, which obviously didn't fix the error when I tried it.

I was able to reproduce this in a fresh workspace with a fresh project. My specific steps:
1. Created a new project through the "New Ceylon Project" wizard. Gave it a name and kept all defaults.
2. Created new module in the source directory using the "New Ceylon Module" wizard. Gave it a name but kept defaults.
3. Added to `import ceylon.math.float {random}` to the top of the run.ceylon file. 
4. Wrong quick fix suggestion then appeared.

When I click the quick fix it will add `import java.auth "7";` to the module.ceylon file. If I manually change it to `import ceylon.math "1.1.0";` everything works fine and the example program runs. If I remove it the same problem comes back though.

I believe I am on the latest Eclipse version and the latest Ceylon IDE plugin version. Specifically:

Eclipse Platform Version: 4.4.2.v20150204-1700
Ceylon IDE: 1.1.0.v20141013-1438-Final

Here is a screenshot of the problem with the project structure open on the left:

![screen shot 2015-02-28 at 10 55 39 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11252611/6429523/6cdca44c-bf9d-11e4-9f39-5840636e9d00.png)

issues.title: removal of DeclarationWithProject broke OpenDeclarationDialog
issues.body: Declaration.equals() doesn't take into account the actual archive/source folder containing the declaration, so we _do_ need to wrap the Declaration in a proxy with a different notion of equality.

Better management of step through default argument code for #1260 :

- Option to Step Into / Step Through default argument code

Better naming of default parameter methods, since now with @tombentley
change in #1260, we can step into default parameter code nicely.

issues.body:
Given:

``` ceylon
shared void bar() => foo();

shared void foo(Integer integer=1) 
        => print("goodbye");
```

When I debug this code, I stop in a stack frame with no line number information, between the body of `bar()` and the body of `foo()`. I assume this is the nullary `foo()` method that fills in the default argument values. Apparently it has no line number information.

2. the debugger should skip it.

@davidfestal @tombentley  thoughts?

issues.title: ModelResolutionException when a jar lib is imported + IDE and CLI do not see the same methods
issues.body:
The symptom is this error in the IDE :

```
UnitDependencyVisitor caused an exception visiting ImportMember node: com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.loader.ModelResolutionException:
JDT reference binding without a JDT IType element ! at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.JDTModelLoader.toType(JDTModelLoader.java:932)
```

To reproduce, start with this Ceylon code (JVM backend)

``` ceylon
import org.gradle.api {
    Project
}
shared class Foo(shared Project project){
}  
```

The `Project` Java class comes from a gradle jar (the jar was imported in my Ceylon repos : it is **gradle-core-2.2.1.jar** in the Gradle distrib).So the module descriptor looks like this :

``` ceylon
module com.sgalles "1.0.0" {
     shared import gradlecore "2.2.1";
} 
```

Then perform a **clean** of the project, you get the error :

```
UnitDependencyVisitor caused an exception visiting ImportMember node: com.redhat.ceylon.compiler.loader.ModelResolutionException:
JDT reference binding without a JDT IType element ! at com.redhat.ceylon.eclipse.core.model.JDTModelLoader.toType(JDTModelLoader.java:932)
```

Then, I had to force a save on the ceylon source of the class to make this error goes away.

issues.title: Building with (pure) Eclipse fails on Java 8
issues.body:
1- For this you need to have Java 8 installed and configured as your default Java compiler/runtime (`java -version` and `javac -version` should return 1.8).

2- You will also need the `rt.jar` and `jce.jar` from a Java 7 installation.

3- Then create the file `ceylon-common/user-build.properties` with the following contents:

```
compile.java.bootclasspath=/usr/java/jdk1.7.0_71/jre/lib/rt.jar:/usr/java/jdk1.7.0_71/jre/lib/jce.jar
```

(where you will need to edit the 2 paths to point to the actual location of the 2 JARs on your system).

4- Now follow the normal build procedure of `ant clean publish ide-quick` in the `ceylon-dist` and `ceylon.formatter` projects.

5- You should do the Maven build for the Eclipse plugin and install it in Eclipse (which should also be running Java 8!) to see that everything works just fine.

The problem comes when you try to run the Eclipse plugin as an Eclipse application.

issues.title: ceylon compiler does not pick up java interface in default package
issues.body:
1. Create a new Ceylon project. 
2. Add a Java interface `public interface I {}` to the default package.
3. Add the Ceylon function `void run(I i) {}` to the default package.

Notice that the function does not compile.

Moving the Java interface to a different package, and `import`ing it, solves the problem.

issues.title: Run As > Ceylon Java Application is messed up
issues.body:
- With `void test() {}` and **Run > Run As > Ceylon Java Application** I get a dialog box "No ceylon runnable element". There should be an explanation that it needs to be shared.
- If I make `test()` shared I can run it. If I then make is non-shared I can _still_ run it via **Run > Run History > ...**. I should get the same response as when I try to run it directly.
- If I add a non-defaulted parameter to `test()` (it's shared again now) then and I try to run it not via history I get the same dialog.
- But if I run it out of the history again then I get an error message in the dialog:
  
  > ceylon run: Cannot run toplevel method 'jsonsl.test': it should have no
  >   parameters or they should all have default values.
  
  But this message doesn't mention the need for `shared`!

issues.title: Highlight occurrences when cursor on type constraint

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
treat type constraint like reference instead of refinement
fix #1200

issues.body:
I have a type declaration like this:

``` ceylon
interface Foo<Bar, Gee>
    satisfies Example<Bar>
   given Bar satisfies Other<Nothing> {
}
```

If I put the cursor on the `Bar` type constraint then the other `Bar`s in the declaration get highlighted, but if I put the cursor on the `Bar` type parameter or the `Bar` type argument, then the `Bar` in the type constraint does _not_ get highlighted. I find this lack of symmetry disturbing (though I suppose it might have a justification in the use of `Bar` _as a type_).

issues.title: Inlining expressions with operators is broken
Null-safe invoking "first" attribute on a tuple
issues.body:
Edit: I was mistaken, this isn't IDE-specific. I've reported it for ceylon-compiler.

---

The IDE doesn't like this code (works fine with CLI):

```
void foo([String, Integer]? bar) {
    value baz = bar?.first;
}
```

| Description | Location | Type |
| --- | --- | --- |
| incompatible types (required ceylon.language.String, found java.lang.Object) | line 2 | Ceylon Backend Error |
| Some classes are missing from the generated module archives, probably because of an unexpected error in the Java backend compiler. (The detail of missing classes is given in the Information markers.) | Unknown | Ceylon Backend Error |
| The Ceylon Java backend compiler failed abnormally (with 1 malformed Javac tree cases, with a throwable : java.lang.RuntimeException: Error generating bytecode for…) | line 0 | Ceylon Backend Error |

Compiles fine with `Tuple.last`, null-safe method invocations, and if `bar` has type `[String]`.

issues.title: Completion for Integer|Float VS Float|Integer
issues.body:
For the type `Integer|Float`, the IDE completion proposes methods from `Comparable<Integer>`, and for the type `Float|Integer` it proposes methods from `Comparable<Float>`
But of course, the real supertype is `Comparable<Nothing>` and it should just filter these methods out.

issues.title: Character / String literal documentation is terminated by null character

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
improve hover for string/character literals
fix #1186

issues.body:
``` ceylon
Character c = '\{#0000}';
```

Place the cursor inside the character literal.
Expected content of Ceylon Documentation view (Shift+Alt+Q D):

> Character literal
> ''
> Unicode Name: NULL
> Codepoint: U+0000
> General Category: Other, control
> Script: COMMON
> Block: BASIC_LATIN

Actual content:

> Character literal:
> '

Similarly, the documentation for the string literal `"Hello, \{#0000}World!"` only displays

> String literal
> "Hello, 

The console also only displays that part when the string is printed, but the console isn’t provided by this plugin, so this isn’t our problem.

Can we even fix this? Perhaps it’s just a problem with C’s string design (null-terminated strings instead of storing the length) which enters Eclipse via SWT; in that case, I have no problem with closing this issue as CANTFIX or something.

The command line tools will always build and run the module without issue.

module mwe "0.1" {

}

shared package mwe;

import ceylon.html {

import ceylon.html.serializer {

issues.title: Disable formatter indent preferences by default
issues.body:
So we have reproduced one of the very worst design mistakes in JDT, namely, that we now have two different places to set the auto-indent: in the Text Editors preferences, and in the Formatter Profiles project preferences.

Luckily, the formatter right now actually just ignores the settings in Formatter Profiles and uses the Text Editors preferences for indenting. Given that, we should at the very least grey out the preferences which are ignored, I guess giving the user a way to enable those if they really want to.

issues.title: Format selection can insert indentation mid-line
HTML escapes in quick fix labels
issues.body:
``` ceylon
Object?&Identifiable s = 1;
```

The quick fix on `= 1` reads:

> Change type of 's' to 'Integer|lt;Object?gt;amp;Identifiable

should be

> Change type of 's' to 'Integer|<Object>&Identifiable'

(Not specific to this code; also happens, for example, in the “Declare explicit type” quick fix.
